c74object.name: bach.eval
c74object.description: Evaluates expressions with variables, branching, loops and user-defined functions.

objarg.name: expression
objarg.description: The syntax of the expression is based upon bach.expr's, but it can contain branching and loop statements, and user-defined variables and functions. For a complete description of the expression syntax, please refer to the help file.

method.name: (doubleclick)
method.description: Double-clicking on the object forces a text editor to open up, where the expression can be edited directly.

method.name: (doubleclick)
method.digest: Edit bell code for lambda attribute
method.description: Doubleclicking on the object forces a text editor to open up, where the bell code for the lambda attribute can be edited directly.

method.name: bang
method.description: Return the comparison result for the most recently received lllls.

method.name: bang
method.description: Return the result of the evaluation of the most recently received lllls and expression.

method.name: expr
method.description: The expr message, followed by a valid expression, will set the new expression to be evaluated by bach.eval. For more details on the expression syntax, please refer to bach.eval's help patcher.

method.name: forceread
method.digest: Read code from file even if incorrect
method.description: Loads a file containing bell code into the object, but ignore it if the code is invalid.

method.name: forcereadappend
method.digest: Read code from file and append it even if incorrect
method.description: Appends the contents of a file containing bell code to the code already owned by the object, keeping it even if it is invalid.

method.name: llll
method.digest: Store values for the expression variables
method.description: The lllls provide the data to the expression. An llll received in the leftmost inlet will trigger the evaluation and cause the result to be output.

method.name: read
method.description: Loads a file containing bell code into the object, keeping it even if it is invalid.

method.name: readappend
method.digest: Read code from file and append it
method.description: Appends the contents of a file containing bell code to the code already owned by the object, but ignore it if the code is invalid.

method.name: write
method.description: Writes the bell code into a file.

attribute.name: auto
attribute.description: When set to 1, the stored code is automatically run at startup. This is a static attribute which can only be set by typing it in the object box.

attribute.name: directins
attribute.description:
Number of direct inlets.
This is a static attribute which can only be set by typing it in the object box.

attribute.name: directouts
attribute.description:
Number of direct outlets.
This is a static attribute which can only be set by typing it in the object box.

attribute.name: embed
attribute.description: When set to 1, the stored code is saved with the patcher.

attribute.name: extraoutlets
attribute.description:
Number of data outlets.
This is a static attribute which can only be set by typing it in the object box.

attribute.name: file
attribute.digest: Code file to be read at initialization
attribute.description: The file attribute allows setting a file name to be loaded automatically when the object is created. Its contents override those of the code in both the object box and the editor. This is a static attribute which can only be set by typing it in the object box.

attribute.name: label
attribute.value: Code file to be read at initialization

attribute.name: inlets
attribute.description:
Number of data inlets.
This is a static attribute which can only be set by typing it in the object box.

attribute.name: lambda
attribute.description: The lambda attribute allows setting a snipped of bell code to be called instead of the lambda loop. If the lambda attribute is set, the lambda loop will not be evaluated, and the provided code will be executed as well. For each lambda outlet of the object, an input pseudovariable is passed to the lambda loop, with their indices counted from left to right.

attribute.name: lambdaparams
attribute.description: The lambdaparams attribute allows setting the values of local variables to be passed to the bell code set by the lambda attribute. It is structured as an llll consisting of one or more sublists, each containing the name of a variable and its value to be passed to the code. For example, the llll [ $foo 1 ] [ $bar [ 2 3 ] ] will set the $foo and $bar local variables respectively to 1 and [ 2 3 ].

attribute.name: maxtime
attribute.description: The maxtime attribute allows setting a maximum evaluation time in milliseconds for the bell code provided. If it is reached, the evaluation aborts and the code returns null. If maxtime is set to 0, there is no time limit. The default is 60000 ms (1 minute).

attribute.name: out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the following:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message. To keep the representation invertible (i.e., to allow a bach object receiving a text-format llll to interpret it exactly as if it was native format, except for the size limitation), some specific kinds of symbols are preceded by a backtick: namely, symbols containing parens, or containing textual representations of numbers or pitches, or beginning with a backtick, plus the symbols "null" and "nil" (distinct from the reserved words "null" and "nil" representing the empty list and the empty sublist) are preceded by a backtick. Moreover, the symbols "int", "float" or "list" are preceded by a backtick only if they are the first element of an llll, to distinguish them from the corresponding reserved messages of Max.
m: 'max' output: mostly equivalent to the "t" specifier, but no symbol is backticket except "int", "float" and "list" at the beginning of an llll. It is important to notice that, differently from text-format lllls proper, Max-format lllls might not be invertible even if they do not reach the size limit for Max message. This means that a bach object receiving a Max-format llll output from another bach object might interpret it differently from the original, or in some cases might even reject it.
x: disabled output (nothing is output)
p: 'portal' output: only used by bach.portal to intercept the @out attribute specified while creating the abstraction (see bach.portal).
The native output is recommended, unless communication with standard Max messages is needed. Disabling unused outputs can be useful if extreme optimization of the patch is needed.
This is a static attribute which can only be set by typing it in the object box.

attribute.name: params
attribute.description: The params attribute allows setting the values of local variables to be passed to the code. It is structured as an llll consisting of one or more sublists, each containing the name of a variable and its value to be passed to the code. For example, the llll [ $foo 1 ] [ $bar [ 2 3 ] ] will set the $foo and $bar local variables respectively to 1 and [ 2 3 ].

attribute.name: triggers
attribute.description:
An llll setting which data inlets are "hot" (i.e., which will will trigger the result) and which global and patcher variables must cause the re-evaluation of the program when assigned a new value. Inlets are counted from 1. 0 means that all data inlets are hot. Negative indices are counted from the right, but only considering data inlets, excluding direct inlets which are always cold anyway. (e.g., -1 means the rightmost data inlet). null means that all inlets are cold, but a bang in any inlet will still cause the llll to be output.
The llll can contain names of global and patcher variables (the latter preceded by a # sign): whenever any of those variables takes a new value, the expression will be re-evaluated.
Sublists composed of a variable name and an integer will treat the integer as the variable auto-evaluation priority: if different objects register to the same variable with different priorities, when the value of the variable changes they will be evaluated according to each's priority, from highest to lowest. The default is 0.
Three special wildcard tokens can be included in the trigger lists:
- * includes all the patcher and global variables used in the code;
- .* includes all the global variables used in the code;
- .# includes all the patcher variables used in the code.
Wildcards can also have a priority, with the same syntax as regular variables.
An important caveat concerning patcher variables is that the ones declared as triggers affect the variable hierarchies, even if they do not appear in the expression.
Examples:
1 2 foo [ #bar 10 ] -1 will cause the first, second and rightmost data inlets to be hot, and the foo global variable and bar patcher variable to trigger the evaluation, with priorities respectively of 0 and 10.
#* [ .* -10 ] 1 will cause all the patcher and global variables in the code to trigger the evaluation, respectively with a priority of 0 and -10; moreover, data received the first inlet will trigger the evaluation, too.

attribute.name: watch
attribute.description: If the watch attribute is set to 1 (as by default), whenever the loaded bell code file or one of the files included by the code is changed the code is reloaded and rebuilt.
